title: Understanding the Quantum Number ℓ
text: The quantum number ℓ, also known as the azimuthal or angular momentum quantum number, determines the shape of the electron's orbital. It can take on integer values from $$0$$ to $$n-1$$, where $$n$$ is the principal quantum number.

title: Letter Designation for $$ℓ=2$$
text:
Each value of ℓ corresponds to a specific letter designation:
- $$ℓ=0$$ is 's'
- $$ℓ=1$$ is 'p'
- $$ℓ=2$$ is 'd'
- $$ℓ=3$$ is 'f'

For $$ℓ=2$$, the letter designation is 'd'.

title: Possible mℓ Values for $$ℓ=2$$
text: The magnetic quantum number mℓ can take on integer values from -ℓ to $$+l$$, including zero. For $$ℓ=2$$, mℓ can be $$-2$$, $$-1$$, $$0$$, $$1$$, or $$2$$. This gives us $$5$$ possible values.

title: Number of Orbitals in $$ℓ=2$$ Subshell
text: Each unique mℓ value corresponds to a different orbital. Since there are $$5$$ possible mℓ values for $$ℓ=2$$, there are $$5$$ orbitals in the $$d$$ subshell.

title: Maximum Number of Electrons in $$ℓ=2$$ Subshell
text: Each orbital can hold a maximum of $$2$$ electrons. With $$5$$ orbitals in the $$d$$ subshell, the maximum number of electrons is $$5\times2=10$$.
